headline.main: Graff Diamonds Is Said To Be Planning $1 Billion I.P.O.

docs.snippet: HONG KONG - While Wall Street is busy with Facebook's debut on the Nasdaq, investors in Hong Kong, the world's biggest market for new listings, are focused on whether diamonds really are forever - or at least long enough to shine above the current...
docs.abstract: British gemstone retailer Graff Diamonds plans to raise up to $1 billion in an initial public offering in Hong Kong that could value the business at up to $4 billion. (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG - While Wall Street is busy with Facebook's debut on the Nasdaq, investors in Hong Kong, the world's biggest market for new listings, are focused on whether diamonds really are forever - or at least long enough to shine above the current volatility in global markets. Graff Diamonds, the family-owned British retailer of the luxury gemstones, plans to raise up to $1 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering that could value the business at up to $4 billion, two people with direct knowledge of the transaction said Friday.

headline.main: Crawford Greenewalt Jr., 74; Shed Light on an Ancient City

docs.snippet: Professor Greenewalt, an archaeologist, transformed scholars’ understanding of Sardis, now western Turkey....

keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS
keywords.name: glocations

docs.abstract: Crawford Greenewalt Jr, archaeologist, dies at age 74. Photo, Maps (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Crawford Greenewalt Jr., an archaeologist whose work over half a century helped illuminate the lives of king and commoner in the ancient city of Sardis, died on May 4 in Hockessin, Del. He was 74. His death, of a brain tumor, was announced by the University of California, Berkeley, where he was an emeritus professor of classical archaeology.

docs.snippet: It appears that all is not right inside the classic rock band Van Halen.  The veteran rockers announced late Thursday that they were postponing more than 30 dates on their current tour to promote their new album, ''A Different Kind of Truth,'' The...
docs.abstract: Veteran classic-rock band Van Halen announces they are postponing more than 30 dates on their current tour to promote their latest album A Different Kind of Truth; offer no explanation for the decision. Photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It appears that all is not right inside the classic rock band Van Halen. The veteran rockers announced late Thursday that they were postponing more than 30 dates on their current tour to promote their new album, ''A Different Kind of Truth,'' The Associated Press and CNN reported. There was no immediate explanation for the decision. The band, whose members have quarreled in the past, has said it will put off indefinitely all tour dates after a June 26 show in New Orleans, including shows in Milwaukee, Detroit, Cleveland, Salt Lake City and El Paso.

headline.main: CHELSEA WINS SHOOTOUT, 4-3; Penalty Kicks Made and Missed Lift Chelsea

docs.snippet: Bayern Munich controlled play throughout the Champions League final, but Chelsea’s Didier Drogba scored the tying goal and converted the decisive penalty kick in the shootout....
docs.abstract: Chelsea defeats Bayern Munich in a 4-3 shootout to win European Champions League soccer title; teams were tied 1-1 at the end of regulation, with Chelsea striker Didier Drogba scoring the tying goal and then converting the decisive penalty kick. Photos (M)d
docs.lead_paragraph: MUNICH -- Didier Drogba gave Chelsea life, then nearly caused its demise in the final of the European Champions League on Saturday night. Given a reprieve after his mistake in extra time, Drogba converted the penalty kick against Bayern Munich that gave the Blues the most coveted title in club soccer for the first time.

docs.snippet: RALEIGH--Thomas. 20 years gone today your kind-hearted ways are still remembered....
docs.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH--Thomas. 20 years gone today your kind-hearted ways are still remembered.

headline.main: Jets Sign Bell, a Veteran Safety

docs.snippet: The Jets continued their off-season overhaul at safety Friday, signing the veteran Yeremiah Bell to a one-year deal worth $1.4 million. Bell, who spent the previous eight seasons with the Miami Dolphins, provides the Jets with a durable, in-the-bo...
docs.abstract: New York Jets sign the veteran safety Yeremiah Bell to a one-year deal worth $1.4 million. (S)6
docs.lead_paragraph: The Jets continued their off-season overhaul at safety Friday, signing the veteran Yeremiah Bell to a one-year deal worth $1.4 million. Bell, who spent the previous eight seasons with the Miami Dolphins, provides the Jets with a durable, in-the-box safety who is regarded more for his run defense than his pass coverage. The 34-year-old Bell, released by the Dolphins for salary-cap reasons, started 63 of Miami's last 64 regular-season games and led the team in tackles in each of the last four years. In 2011, Bell had 107 tackles, 2 sacks and an interception. With Eric Smith and LaRon Landry, signed as a free agent in March, projected to start for the Jets, it is unlikely that Bell approaches those statistics again this season. But he supplies valuable depth at a position that lacked consistency in 2011 and that lost its primary backup, Brodney Pool, to a free-agent deal in Dallas.

headline.main: Big Debut Is Marred By Problems At Nasdaq

docs.snippet: Friday should have been Facebook's day to shine -- and Nasdaq's as well.     Instead it became a glitch-filled market session that raised questions about how Facebook's stock price ended the day as well as how the nation's second-biggest stock mar...
docs.abstract: Facebook's highly-anticipated initial public offering is marred by technical problems on the Nasdaq exchange that lead to extensive delays; shares end the day at $38.23, only marginally higher than the $38 offer price, leading to criticism of underwriter Morgan Stanley; Securities and Exchange Commission plans to investigate the glitches. Photos, Chart (M)

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and EVELYN M. RUSLI

docs.lead_paragraph: Friday should have been Facebook's day to shine -- and Nasdaq's as well. Instead it became a glitch-filled market session that raised questions about how Facebook's stock price ended the day as well as how the nation's second-biggest stock market and the underwriters handled the trading debut. The Securities and Exchange Commission said that it would review the day's trading, which included an unexpected delay, missing trade execution messages and at one point, having to fill orders by hand.

headline.main: Like the Video? I Wrote the Book

docs.snippet: The drudgery of writing the book is over. So where’s the good stuff?...
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Tim Kreider contends that the publishing world is in a state of cluelessness and desperation and as a result has turned to urging authors to engage on social media and to make video trailers for their books; observes that his expectations of what would happen when he finished his book bear little resemblance to the reality. Drawing (M)2
docs.lead_paragraph: THE first time I'd ever heard that there were video previews for books was when I was told I had to make one. A few months before my own book was to be released, my publisher advised me that official book trailers were now routinely posted on YouTube as a promotional device. I was skeptical, but remembering how instrumental video was in advancing the career of Men Without Hats, I acquiesced. The first script I submitted was reverse-engineered from a survey of viral videos: it featured a hot girl, my cat, a catchy song and a child being humiliated. It was ix-nayed without much discussion -- presumably because it was not remotely SFW -- so I dutifully wrote a more conventional version whose only concession to plebeian taste was a brief image of Ulysses S. Grant in drag. Filming this video was not exactly grueling, since it forced my friend and co-star Boyd to visit me in New York and required us to drink free beer before noon. My own reaction on seeing the final cut was to contemplate, for the first time in my life, getting cosmetic surgery, but people who've seen it tell me it's funny and melancholic and successfully conveys the spirit of the book. I now have hopes, I think not wholly unjustified, of joining that pantheon shared by the Star Wars Kid, Obama Girl and the internationally renowned cat Maru.

docs.snippet: Why Elizabeth Warren’s embarrassment is a scandal for academia....
docs.abstract: Ross Douthat Op-Ed column asserts that the issue of Elizabeth Warren's apocryphal Native American heritage has been an embarrassment for her campaign for United States Senate, but offers colleges and universities an opportunity to rethink the pursuit of cosmetic diversity on their campuses. (M)/
docs.lead_paragraph: ''I still have a picture on my mantel and it is a picture my mother had before that -- a picture of my grandfather. And my Aunt Bea has walked by that picture at least a thousand times [and] remarked that he -- her father, my papaw -- had high cheekbones like all of the Indians do. ... Being Native American has been part of my story, I guess, since the day I was born.'' -- Elizabeth Warren, Democratic Senate candidate in Massachusetts, trying to explain why she identified herself as a ''minority'' law professor in the 1980s and 1990s.

headline.main: Proposal Backs Hepatitis C Test For Baby Boomers

docs.snippet: Anyone born from 1945 to 1965 should get a one-time blood test to see if they have the virus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in draft recommendations on Friday....

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention proposes that all baby boomers born from 1945 to 1965 get tested for hepatitis C. (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The government is proposing that all baby boomers get tested for hepatitis C. Anyone born from 1945 to 1965 should get a one-time blood test to see if they have the liver-destroying virus, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in draft recommendations on Friday. Baby boomers account for more than 2 million of the 3.2 million Americans infected with the virus. It is most commonly spread now by sharing needles to inject drugs. Before the widespread screening of blood donations began in 1992, it was also spread through transfusions. Health officials believe that hundreds of thousands of infections occurred each year in the 1970s and 1980s, most of them in baby boomers.
